info.title: Analyzing Performance Metrics Using the Performance Co-Pilot Analysis Toolkit

listitem.para: Initial version

info.meta: The toolkit that collects performance metrics from the system

listitem.para: For performance monitoring purposes, SUSE Linux Enterprise Micro provides a container image that enables you to run the Performance Co-Pilot (PCP) analysis toolkit in a container.
You want to monitor performance on your system, and this article provides information on how to configure and use the toolkit.
It takes approximately 40 minutes of reading time.
You will be able to start the PCP container with a configuration that suits your needs.
A running instance of SLE Micro.

section.para: The toolkit comprises tools for gathering and processing performance information collected either in real time or from PCP archive logs.

The performance data is collected by performance metrics domain agents and passed to the pmcd daemon. The daemon coordinates the gathering and exporting of performance statistics in response to requests from the PCP monitoring tools. pmlogger is then used to log the metrics. For details, refer to the PCP documentation.
The PCP container image is based on the BCI-Init container that utilizes systemd used to manage the PCP services.
You can pull the container image using Podman or from the Cockpit Web management console. To pull the image by using Podman, run the following command:
To get the container image using Cockpit, go to Podman containers, click Get new image, and search for pcp. Then select the image from the registry.suse.com for SLE 15 SP4 and download it.
The following command shows minimal options that you need to use to run a PCP container:
section.screen: # podman run -d \ --systemd always \ -p HOST_IP:HOST_PORT:CONTAINER_PORT \ -v HOST_DIR:/var/log/pcp/pmlogger \ PCP_CONTAINER_IMAGE
section.para: where the options have the following meaning:

listitem.para: The container runs in a detached mode without tty.
Runs the container in the systemd mode. All services needed to run in the PCP container are started automatically by systemd in the container.
The container runs with extended privileges. Use this option if your system has SELinux enabled, otherwise the collected metrics are incomplete.
Creates a bind mount so that pmlogger archives are written to the HOST_DIR on the host. By default, pmlogger stores the collected metrics in /var/log/pcp/pmlogger.
Is the downloaded PCP container image.

section.para: Other useful options of the podman run command follow:

listitem.para: Publishes ports of the container by mapping a container port onto a host port. If you do not specify HOST_IP, the ports are mapped on the local host. If you omit the HOST_PORT value, a random port number is used. By default, the pmcd daemon listens on and exposes the PMAPI to receive metrics on the port 44321, so we recommend mapping this port on the same port number on the host. The pmproxy daemon listens on and exposes the REST PMWEBAPI to access metrics on the 44322 port by default, so it is recommended to map this port on the same host port number.
The container uses the host's network. Use this option to collect metrics from the host's network interfaces.
The option enables you to set the following environment variables:
Is a comma-separated list of services to start by systemd in the container.
Default services are: pmcd, pmie, pmlogger, pmproxy.
You can use this variable to run a container with a list of services that is different from the default one, for example, only with pmlogger:
listitem.screen: # podman run -d \ --name pmlogger \ --systemd always \ -e PCP_SERVICES=pmlogger \ -v pcp-archives:/var/log/pcp/pmlogger \ registry.suse.com/suse/pcp:latest

listitem.para: Is a path inside the container to the bind mount of the host's root file system. The default value is not set.

Specifies a connection to a Redis server. In a non-clustered setup, provide a comma-separated list of host specs. In a clustered setup, provide any individual cluster host, other hosts in the cluster are discovered automatically. The default value is: localhost:6379.
If you need to use a different configuration than the one provided by the environment variables, proceed as described in .

section.para: All services that run inside the PCP container have a default configuration that might not suit your needs. If you need a custom configuration that cannot be covered by the environment variables, create configuration files for the PCP services and pass them to the PCP using a bind mount as follows:
section.screen: # podman run -d \ --name CONTAINER_NAME \ --systemd always \ -v $HOST_CONFIG:CONTAINER_CONFIG_PATH:z \ -v HOST_LOGS_PATH:/var/log/pcp/pmlogger \ registry.suse.com/suse/pcp:latest
section.para: Where:

listitem.para: Is an optional container name.
Is an absolute path to the config you created on the host machine. You can choose any file name you want.
Is an absolute path to a particular configuration file inside the container. Each available configuration file is described in the corresponding sections further.
Is a directory that should be a bind mount to the container logs.

section.title: Custom pmcd daemon configuration
section.para: The pmcd daemon configuration is stored in the /etc/sysconfig/pmcd file. The file stores environment variables that modify the behavior of the pmcd daemon.
You can add the following variables to the /etc/sysconfig/pmcd file to configure the pmcd daemon:

listitem.para: Defines whether the remote host can connect to the pmcd daemon. If set to 0, remote connections to the daemon are allowed. If set to 1, the daemon listens only on the local host. The default value is 0.
Defines the maximum count of pending connections to the agent. The default value is 5.

If the pmdaroot is enabled (the value is set to 1), adding a new PDMA does not trigger restarting of other PMDAs. If pmdaroot is not enabled, pmcd will require restarting all PMDAs when a new PMDA is added. The default value is 1.
If set to 1, the pmcd daemon tries to restart any exited PMDA. Enable this option only if you have enabled pmdaroot, as pmcd itself does not have privileges to restart PMDA.
Defines the maximum time in seconds pmcd can wait to accept a connection. After this time, the connection is reported as failed. The default value is 60.

Defines the mode in which pmcd initializes the NSS certificate database when secured connections are used. The default value is readonly. You can set the mode to readwrite, but if the initialization fails, the default value is used as a fallback.

section.para: An example follows:
section.screen: PMCD_LOCAL=0 PMCD_MAXPENDING=5 PMCD_ROOT_AGENT=1 PMCD_RESTART_AGENTS=1 PMCD_WAIT_TIMEOUT=70 PCP_NSS_INIT_MODE=readwrite

section.title: Custom pmlogger configuration
section.para: The custom configuration for the pmlogger is stored in the following configuration files:

section.title: The /etc/sysconfig/pmlogger file
section.para: You can use the following attributes to configure the pmlogger:

listitem.para: Defines whether pmlogger allows connections from remote hosts. If set to 1, pmlogger allows connections from a local host only.
Defines the maximum count of pending connections. The default value is 5.
Defines the default sampling interval pmlogger uses. The default value is 60 s. Keep in mind that this value can be overridden by the pmlogger command line.

Setting this option to yes disables the regeneration and checking of the pmlogger configuration if the configuration pmlogger comes from pmlogconf. The default behavior is to regenerate configuration files and check for changes every time pmlogger is started.

section.para: An example follows:

section.title: The /etc/pcp/pmlogger/control.d/local file
section.para: The file /etc/pcp/pmlogger/control.d/local stores specifications of the host, which metrics should be logged, the logging frequency (default is 24 hours), and pmlogger options. For example:
section.screen:
# === VARIABLE ASSIGNMENTS === # # DO NOT REMOVE OR EDIT THE FOLLOWING LINE $version=1.1
# Uncomment one of the lines below to enable/disable compression behaviour # that is different to the pmlogger_daily default. # Value is days before compressing archives, 0 is immediate compression, # "never" or "forever" suppresses compression. # #$PCP_COMPRESSAFTER=0 #$PCP_COMPRESSAFTER=3 #$PCP_COMPRESSAFTER=never
# === LOGGER CONTROL SPECIFICATIONS === # #Host P? S? directory args
# local primary logger LOCALHOSTNAME y n PCP_ARCHIVE_DIR/LOCALHOSTNAME -r -T24h10m -c config.default -v 100Mb

note.title: Defaults point to local host
note.para: If you run the pmlogger in a container on a different machine than the one that runs the pmcd (a client), change the following line to point to the client:
note.screen: # local primary logger CLIENT_HOSTNAME y n PCP_ARCHIVE_DIR/CLIENT_HOSTNAME -r -T24h10m -c config.default -v 100Mb
note.para: For example, for the slemicro_1 host name, the line should look as follows:
note.screen: # local primary logger slemicro_1 y n PCP_ARCHIVE_DIR/slemicro_1 -r -T24h10m -c config.default -v 100Mb

section.para: From within the container, you can use the command pminfo to list metrics. For example, to list all available performance metrics, run:
You can list a group of related metrics by specifying the metrics prefix:
For example, to list all metrics related to kernel, use:
section.screen:
# pminfo disk
disk.dev.r_await disk.dm.await disk.dm.r_await disk.md.await disk.md.r_await ...
section.para: You can also specify additional strings to narrow down the list of metrics, for example:
section.screen:
# piminfo disk.dev
disk.dev.read disk.dev.write disk.dev.total disk.dev.blkread disk.dev.blkwrite disk.dev.blktotal ...
section.para: To get online help text of a particular metric, use the -t option followed by the metric, for example:
section.screen:
# pminfo -t kernel.cpu.util.user
kernel.cpu.util.user [percentage of user time across all CPUs, including guest CPU time]
section.para: To display a description text of a particular metric, use the -T option followed by the metric, for example:
section.screen:
# pminfo -T kernel.cpu.util.user
Help: percentage of user time across all CPUs, including guest CPU time

section.para: After you start the PCP container, you can verify that metrics are being recorded properly by running the following command inside the container:
section.screen:
# pcp
Performance Co-Pilot configuration on localhost:
platform: Linux localhost 5.3.18-150300.59.68-default #1 SMP Wed May 4 11:29:09 UTC 2022 (ea30951) x86_64 hardware: 1 cpu, 1 disk, 1 node, 1726MB RAM timezone: UTC services: pmcd pmproxy pmcd: Version 5.2.2-1, 9 agents, 4 clients pmda: root pmcd proc pmproxy xfs linux mmv kvm jbd2 pmlogger: primary logger: /var/log/pcp/pmlogger/localhost/20220607.09.24 pmie: primary engine: /var/log/pcp/pmie/localhost/pmie.log
section.para: Now check if the logs are written to a proper destination:
where PATH_TO_PMLOGGER_LOGS should be /var/log/pcp/pmlogger/localhost/ in this case.

You can deploy collector containers that collect metrics from different remote systems than the ones where the pmlogger containers are running. Each remote collector system needs the pmcd daemon and a set of pmda. To deploy several collectors with a centralized monitoring system, proceed as follows.

step.para: On each system you want to collect metrics from (clients), run a container with the pmcd daemon:
step.screen: # podman run -d \ --name pcp-pmcd \ --privileged \ --net host \ --systemd always \ -e PCP_SERVICES=pmcd \ -e HOST_MOUNT=/host \ -v /:/host:ro,rslave \ registry.suse.com/suse/pcp:latest

step.para: On the monitoring system, create a pmlogger configuration file for each client control.CLIENT with the following content:
Keep in mind that the CLIENT_HOSTNAME must be resolvable in DNS. You can use IP addresses or fully qualified domain names (FQDN) instead.
On the monitoring system, create a directory for each client to store the recorded logs:
On the monitoring system, run a container with pmlogger for each client:
step.screen: # podman run -d \ --name pcp-pmlogger-CLIENT \ --systemd always \ -e PCP_SERVICES=pmlogger \ -v /root/pcp-archives/CLIENT:/var/log/pcp/pmlogger:z \ -v $(pwd)/control.CLIENT:/etc/pcp/pmlogger/control.d/local:z \ registry.suse.com/suse/pcp:latest
step.para: For example, for a client called slemicro_1:
step.screen: # podman run -d \ --name pcp-pmlogger-slemicro_1 \ --systemd always \ -e PCP_SERVICES=pmlogger \ -v /root/pcp-archives:/var/log/pcp/pmlogger:z \ -v $(pwd)/control.slemicro_1:/etc/pcp/pmlogger/control.d/local:z \ registry.suse.com/suse/pcp:latest

note.para: The second bind mount points to the configuration file created in and replaces the default pmlogger configuration. If you do not create this bind mount, pmlogger uses the default /etc/pcp/pmlogger/control.d/local file and logging from clients fails as the default configuration points to a local host. For details about the configuration file, refer to .

step.para: To check if the log collection is working properly, run:
step.screen:
# ls -l pcp-archives/slemicro_1/slemicro_1
total 1076 -rw-r--r--. 1 systemd-network systemd-network 876372 Jun 8 11:24 20220608.10.58.0 -rw-r--r--. 1 systemd-network systemd-network 312 Jun 8 11:22 20220608.10.58.index -rw-r--r--. 1 systemd-network systemd-network 184486 Jun 8 10:58 20220608.10.58.meta -rw-r--r--. 1 systemd-network systemd-network 246 Jun 8 10:58 Latest -rw-r--r--. 1 systemd-network systemd-network 24595 Jun 8 10:58 pmlogger.log
